features.title: Auto Complete
features.desc: Predictive suggestions as buyers type, reducing keystrokes and guiding to products faster.
features.value: Critical for part numbers, SKUs, and technical terms. Reduces typos and speeds up known-item search.
features.implementation: Day 1 feature, works immediately with catalog data.

fullContent.whatItSolves: The fundamental friction of typing in a search box. Every keystroke is a chance for typos, especially with technical part numbers and SKUs.
keyValueProps: Reduce keystrokes by 60-80% for known-item searches
Handle part number variations as users type
Guide users toward valid products before they hit Enter
fullContent.b2bContext: In B2B, buyers often search for exact part numbers like "ABC-123-XYZ". Auto-complete that understands format variations (dashes, spaces, leading zeros) is critical. Unlike B2C where suggestions are about discovery, B2B auto-complete is about speed and accuracy.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Works immediately with basic catalog data. Can be enhanced with behavioral data over time to show personalized and trending suggestions. Low risk, high value Day 1 feature.

features.title: Faceted Search
features.desc: Dynamic filters based on product attributes (brand, size, material, voltage, etc.).
features.value: Essential for large catalogs. Lets technical buyers narrow by specs. Shows category depth.
features.implementation: Quality depends on attribute consistency. May need data cleanup first.

fullContent.whatItSolves: Large catalogs (100K+ SKUs) where scrolling through results is impossible. Technical buyers who need to narrow by exact specifications.
keyValueProps: Let technical buyers filter by exact specifications
Dynamic facets that change based on category context
Show category depth and available options
fullContent.b2bContext: Unlike B2C filtering (color, size), B2B facets are technical: voltage, thread pitch, material grade, certification compliance. The quality of faceted search is directly tied to attribute data quality.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Quality depends entirely on attribute consistency. May need data cleanup first. Consider which attributes matter most per category.

features.title: Visual Filters
features.desc: Image-based filter selection (color swatches, shape selectors, visual size comparison).
features.value: Helpful for products where visual identification matters — fittings, connectors, finishes.
features.implementation: Requires image assets and attribute mapping. Consider for high-visual categories.

fullContent.whatItSolves: Products that are easier to identify visually than by spec. "I know it when I see it" scenarios.
keyValueProps: Image-based selection for shape, color, style
Color swatches for finishes and materials
fullContent.b2bContext: Particularly valuable for fittings, connectors, hardware where buyers might not know the technical name but can recognize the shape. Also useful for finish/color selection where text descriptions fail.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Requires quality product images and attribute mapping. Consider for high-visual categories first. Can use AI for image classification.

features.title: Part Number Normalization
features.desc: Acts as a sanitizer, stripping special characters and normalizing whitespace before the search executes. Ensures users never receive zero results simply because they missed a hyphen.
features.value: Critical for industrial buyers who search by part numbers. Handles format variations across 50+ brands with no standard conventions. "ABC-123" = "ABC123" = "ABC 123".
features.implementation: Day 1 feature. Requires character normalization rules, unit equivalency mappings, fraction-to-decimal tables, and confidence scoring for fuzzy match ranking.

fullContent.whatItSolves: Industrial buyers are notorious for inconsistent formatting. One might type "X-100", another "X100", and a third "X 100". This feature acts as a sanitizer, stripping special characters and normalizing whitespace before the search executes. It ensures that a user never receives zero results simply because they missed a hyphen.
fullContent.whyItsHard: There is no standard format. A single manufacturer might use "DW-110", "DW110", "DW 110", "DW.110", and "110-DW" interchangeably. Across 50+ brands, you have 50+ conventions—none documented, none consistent.
fullContent.theBoundaryProblem: We don't know where a part number starts and ends. When a user types "254": Beginning? → "254-100", "254XL". Middle? → "ABC-254-D". End? → "DW-254". Exact? → just "254". With natural language we have spaces and grammar. With part numbers, we have nothing—"ABC123DEF" could be one part or three. There's no way to know without checking every possibility.
fullContent.theTradeoff: Too strict and "DW110" returns nothing when the catalog has "DW-110". Too fuzzy and "DW-110" returns "DW-1100", "DW-11", "DWS-110"—wrong parts, returns, blame.
keyValueProps: Handle dashes, spaces, prefixes, leading zeros across all format variations
Character normalization and substitution rules (O↔0, I↔1)
Confidence scoring for fuzzy match ranking
useCases: SKU Search: User types a messy SKU copied from an old invoice; system matches it to the clean SKU in the database
OCR Errors: OCR misreads "BLM-205" as "BLM-2O5" (zero vs letter O)—fuzzy match catches it
Legacy Numbers: Customer searches old manufacturer part number; system matches to renumbered SKU
Format Chaos: "DW-110", "DW110", "DW 110", "DW.110", and "110-DW" all return the same product
fullContent.b2bContext: This is B2B table stakes. Industrial buyers search by part number 60%+ of the time. If "ABC-123" doesn't match because your catalog has "ABC123", you lose the sale. The challenge isn't just normalization—it's handling 50+ manufacturer conventions with no standard format, no documented rules, and no consistency. All three pillars green — no excuse not to have this Day 1.
otherRequirements: Character normalization and substitution rules (O↔0, I↔1)
Confidence scoring for fuzzy match ranking
fullContent.implementationNotes: Day 1 feature. Configure normalization rules based on your industry patterns. Test with your actual search logs to identify format variations buyers actually use. The boundary problem requires careful tuning—too strict loses sales, too fuzzy causes wrong-part returns and customer blame.

features.title: Voice Search
features.desc: Speak to search — voice input for hands-free or mobile scenarios.
features.value: Useful for field workers, warehouse staff, or anyone with hands occupied.
features.implementation: Browser-based speech recognition. Consider accent/terminology training.

fullContent.whatItSolves: Hands-occupied scenarios: warehouse workers with gloves, field technicians on ladders, mobile users.
fullContent.b2bContext: More valuable in B2B than B2C because of field/warehouse scenarios. The challenge is industry jargon — "three-quarter inch EMT" needs to work, not just standard English.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Browser-based speech recognition works out of the box. Consider accent/terminology training for industry-specific terms. MVP approach: add voice as input method, improve accuracy over time.

features.title: Image Search
features.desc: Upload a photo to find visually similar products using computer vision.
features.value: Field workers photograph unknown parts, maintenance techs replace worn components without labels, buyers match competitor products.
features.implementation: Requires computer vision model and vector index. Can combine with keyword refinement.

fullContent.whatItSolves: Buyers who encounter unknown parts, worn components without readable labels, or competitor products they want to match. Bypasses the need to know technical terminology or part numbers.
keyValueProps: Upload photo to find matching products
Computer vision matches shapes, colors, features
useCases: Technician photographs a broken valve and finds replacement without knowing manufacturer
Procurement uploads competitor catalog image to find equivalent products
Field workers identify unlabeled electrical components by photographing panel markings
Upload image of motor, see compatible belts, pulleys, and mounts as related parts
Combine image of mystery fitting with keyword "brass" to filter results
fullContent.b2bContext: For industrial buyers, the part is often right in front of them but unidentifiable. Image search turns "I need one of these" into a successful product match. Particularly valuable for maintenance, repair, and replacement scenarios.
otherRequirements: Computer vision model for feature extraction
Vector index for image similarity matching
Hybrid query engine supporting image + text fusion
fullContent.implementationNotes: Requires product image library with consistent quality. Multiple angles improve matching accuracy. Can bootstrap with existing catalog images, improve with user-submitted matches over time.

features.title: Universal Search
features.desc: Search across multiple content types — products, documents, support articles, categories.
features.value: Single search box for everything. Buyers find spec sheets, installation guides, and products together.
features.implementation: Requires content indexing strategy. Consider result blending/ranking.

fullContent.whatItSolves: Fragmented search experiences where buyers need different search boxes for products, documentation, and support.
keyValueProps: Single search box for all content
fullContent.b2bContext: B2B buyers often need both the product AND the documentation. Universal search shows "10HP Motor" alongside its spec sheet, wiring diagram, and installation guide. The alternative is frustrated bouncing between different site sections.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Requires content indexing strategy across multiple sources. Consider how to blend and rank results from different content types. Federated search vs unified index decision.

features.title: Searchable Certifications
features.desc: Filter by technical certifications (UL, CSA, RoHS, HazLoc).
features.value: Critical for compliance-driven industries. Buyers need to know it meets code.
features.implementation: Requires structured data. Often buried in PDFs, needs extraction.

fullContent.whatItSolves: Compliance requirements where buyers MUST filter by certification. "Show me only UL-listed products" or "HazLoc rated for Class 1 Div 2".
keyValueProps: Filter by UL, CSA, RoHS, CE, HazLoc ratings
fullContent.b2bContext: In industries like electrical, HVAC, and industrial, certification compliance isn't optional — it's legally required. Buyers need to filter by certification to meet code. This data is often buried in PDFs and needs extraction.
fullContent.implementationNotes: The data challenge: certifications are often in PDF spec sheets, not structured attributes. May need AI extraction or manual enrichment. Critical for compliance-driven industries.

features.title: Semantic Search
features.desc: Understand meaning, not just keywords. "cordless drill" matches "battery-powered drill".
features.value: Bridges vocabulary gaps. Buyers use different terms than your catalog.
features.dataRequired: Rich Catalog (detailed descriptions). Performance improves with better content.
features.implementation: ELSER/BERT models. Quality tied directly to description richness.

alert.text: Sparse descriptions = gimmick feature. Rich descriptions = game-changer.

fullContent.whatItSolves: The vocabulary gap between how buyers search and how your catalog is written. "Cordless drill" should match "battery-powered drill".
keyValueProps: Understand meaning, not just keyword matching
Handle industry jargon and natural language
Improve results without manual synonym lists
fullContent.b2bContext: B2B catalogs are written by product managers using manufacturer terminology. Buyers use field terminology, abbreviations, or "how I describe it" language. Semantic search bridges this gap without endless synonym lists.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Uses ELSER/BERT models. Quality is DIRECTLY tied to description richness. With sparse descriptions ("18V Drill"), semantic search adds nothing. With rich descriptions ("Heavy-duty cordless drill for concrete and masonry..."), it transforms search.

features.title: Intelligent Synonyms
features.desc: Learn and apply industry-specific terminology mappings. Auto-discovers synonyms from behavior.
features.value: Every industry has jargon. "saw blade" vs "circular blade" vs "cutting disc".
features.implementation: Needs monitoring. Bad synonyms can hurt results. Governance required.

fullContent.whatItSolves: Industry-specific terminology that semantic search alone can't handle. Every industry has its own jargon, abbreviations, and alternate names.
keyValueProps: Learn from what buyers actually click
fullContent.b2bContext: Electrical: "wire nut" = "twist-on connector" = "marrette". Industrial: "angle grinder" = "disc grinder" = "side grinder". These industry-specific mappings can't be guessed — they must be learned from your buyers' behavior.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Governance required: bad synonyms can hurt results badly (mapping "drill" to "driver" when they're different products). Needs monitoring and approval workflow. Consider human-in-the-loop for high-volume synonyms.

features.title: Intelligent Auto Complete
features.desc: Context-aware, personalized suggestions based on user history and behavior patterns.
features.value: Shows relevant suggestions first. Electrician sees electrical, plumber sees plumbing.
features.implementation: Builds over time. Cold start with catalog, improves with behavior.

fullContent.whatItSolves: Generic auto-complete shows the same suggestions to everyone. An electrician typing "wire" should see different suggestions than a plumber.
keyValueProps: Personalized suggestions based on user history
Learn from what converts, not just what's searched
fullContent.b2bContext: B2B buyers have specialties. An HVAC contractor searching "motor" wants blower motors, not drill motors. Intelligent auto-complete learns user context and shows relevant suggestions first.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Cold start with catalog data, improves with behavioral data over time. Needs governance because bad personalization is worse than none. Consider showing "why" alongside suggestions.

features.title: Hybrid Search / ML Ranking
features.desc: Blend keyword + semantic + behavioral signals. Machine learning optimizes ranking.
features.value: Best products rise to top based on what actually converts, not just text match.
features.implementation: Expert feature. Requires monitoring, testing, ongoing tuning.

alert.text: High Complexity: All three pillars are red. Consider managed support or phase for later.

fullContent.whatItSolves: Text matching alone doesn't know which products convert. The best result isn't always the closest keyword match — it's the one buyers actually buy.
keyValueProps: Blend keyword, semantic, and behavioral signals
Learn from actual conversions, not just clicks
fullContent.b2bContext: For "safety glasses", keyword search might rank a discontinued model first. ML ranking learns that the current best-seller with 4.8 stars should rank higher. It optimizes for what actually converts.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Expert feature — all three pillars red. Requires 90+ days of behavioral data, ongoing monitoring, and tuning. Consider managed support or phase for post-launch. The ROI is real but so is the complexity.

features.title: Multi-Layered Relevance Funnel
features.desc: Complex ranking strategies combining business rules, personalization, and ML.
features.value: Ultimate control over what appears first — margin, inventory, strategic products.
features.implementation: Most complex feature. Requires expert configuration and ongoing management.

fullContent.whatItSolves: When simple relevance isn't enough. You need to balance text match, business rules (promote high-margin), inventory (hide out-of-stock), and personalization.
fullContent.b2bContext: A distributor might want: (1) In-stock products first, (2) Private label boosted, (3) High-margin in top 3, (4) Relevance within those constraints. Multi-layered relevance makes this possible.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Most complex feature. Requires expert configuration, ongoing tuning, and deep understanding of business objectives. Usually a Day 60-90 feature after simpler ranking is stable.

features.title: Semantic Intent Router
features.desc: Detect what the buyer actually wants — product, category, support, or navigation.
features.value: "Milwaukee" → brand page. "M18 drill" → product. "warranty" → support.
features.implementation: Configure intent rules and destinations. Train on common patterns.

fullContent.whatItSolves: Not all searches want product results. "Milwaukee" might want the brand page. "Warranty" wants support. "How to wire a 3-way switch" wants content.
keyValueProps: Route to brand pages, categories, or support
Reduce frustration from wrong result types
fullContent.b2bContext: "Return policy" shouldn't show products with "return" in the name. "DeWalt 20V" might want the product family page, not a random product. Intent routing sends queries to the right destination.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Configure intent rules based on common patterns. Start with obvious cases (brand names → brand pages, support terms → help), learn and expand over time.

features.title: Recommendation Engine
features.desc: Personalized product suggestions — "frequently bought together", "you may also need".
features.value: Increase basket size. Surface accessories, consumables, related parts.
features.implementation: Cold start challenge. Can bootstrap with rules, improves with behavior.

fullContent.whatItSolves: Missed cross-sell opportunities. When a buyer searches for a drill, they probably also need bits, batteries, and cases.
keyValueProps: Learn from purchase patterns over time
Reduce time to find related products
fullContent.b2bContext: B2B recommendations are about job completion, not impulse buys. "Bought this motor? You'll need mounting hardware, capacitors, and a VFD." Recommendations that understand project context outperform generic "similar products".
fullContent.implementationNotes: Cold start challenge: needs transaction history to work well. Can bootstrap with curated rules ("if drill, show bits"), then improve with behavioral data. Consider showing "why" to build trust.

features.title: Related Searches
features.desc: Suggest alternative query paths when buyers might be stuck or exploring.
features.value: Help buyers discover they searched too narrowly or broadly.
features.implementation: Learns from search patterns. Safe, low-governance feature.

fullContent.whatItSolves: Buyers who searched too narrowly, too broadly, or with the wrong terms. "Did you mean?" and "People also searched for" experiences.
keyValueProps: Help buyers who are stuck or exploring
fullContent.b2bContext: When a buyer searches "3/4 inch copper fitting" and gets too many results, related searches might suggest "3/4 copper elbow", "3/4 copper tee", or "3/4 compression fitting" to narrow down.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Learns from search patterns automatically. Low governance risk — it suggests, doesn't change results. Safe Day 30 feature.

features.title: Cross-Brand Equivalents
features.desc: Show alternative brands and substitutes. "If you're looking for X, consider Y."
features.value: Capture sales when primary brand is out of stock. Help price-conscious buyers.
features.implementation: Requires relationship data. Can use AI to suggest, human to verify.

fullContent.whatItSolves: Brand loyalty meets stock reality. When the preferred brand is out of stock, show equivalent alternatives to capture the sale.
keyValueProps: Capture sales when preferred brand is OOS
fullContent.b2bContext: Industrial buyers often have brand preferences but need the part today. "Milwaukee M18 out of stock? Here's the DeWalt 20V equivalent." Cross-brand equivalents keep the sale instead of losing to a competitor.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Requires relationship data (cross-reference tables). Can use AI to suggest equivalents, but needs human verification — wrong equivalents damage trust. Consider confidence scoring.

features.title: Trending Search
features.desc: Show what's popular now — trending searches, hot products.
features.value: Social proof. Helps buyers see what others are buying. Market signals.
features.implementation: Low governance. Updates automatically based on behavior.

fullContent.whatItSolves: Discovery for buyers who don't know what to search. "What are others buying?" Social proof and market signals.
fullContent.b2bContext: Trending in B2B is about market signals, not viral products. "Searches for generator parts up 400% this week" (hurricane season). Helps buyers see what peers are buying and helps merchandisers spot trends.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Low governance, updates automatically. Consider filtering sensitive searches from trending. Useful Day 30 feature after behavioral data accumulates.

features.title: Custom Products (Kitting)
features.desc: Build bundles and assemblies. Job kits, project packages, custom configurations.
features.value: "Everything you need for X job" — increases order value, reduces buyer effort.
features.implementation: Requires relationship mapping. Can be curated or rule-based.

fullContent.whatItSolves: Complex purchasing where buyers need multiple related items. "I'm wiring a 200A service panel — give me everything I need."
keyValueProps: Pre-built job kits for common tasks
Reduce buyer effort on complex orders
fullContent.b2bContext: Electricians don't want to add 47 items for a service panel job. Kitting lets them search "200A residential service kit" and get everything — panel, breakers, wire, connectors, grounding. Massive time saver.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Requires relationship mapping (what goes with what). Can be merchandiser-curated or rule-based. Start with high-value job kits, expand based on demand.

features.title: Recent Search
features.desc: Show user's recent searches for quick repeat access.
features.value: Critical for B2B. Buyers research today, order tomorrow. Fast return path.
features.implementation: Day 1 feature. Simple, high value, no governance needed.

fullContent.whatItSolves: The "I looked at this yesterday" problem. B2B buyers research and quote before ordering — they need to find what they looked at.
keyValueProps: All three pillars green — no risk
fullContent.b2bContext: B2B buying is rarely one session. Buyers research, get quotes, check with job site, then order. Recent searches bridge sessions. All three pillars green — Day 1 feature with high value.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Day 1 feature. Simple session/account tracking. No governance risk. Consider showing across devices for logged-in users.

features.title: Recently Ordered Section
features.desc: One-click reorder from purchase history. "Buy again" functionality.
features.value: 80% of B2B orders are repeats. This is THE feature for efficiency.
features.implementation: Requires order history integration. High value, relatively simple.

alert.text: B2B Gold: This feature alone can transform repeat purchase efficiency.

fullContent.whatItSolves: The #1 B2B use case: reordering what you bought before. 80% of B2B orders are repeats — this feature addresses the majority of orders.
keyValueProps: Order the exact same item again instantly
Massive time savings for regular buyers
fullContent.b2bContext: This is THE B2B feature. Contractors order the same wire, fittings, and supplies repeatedly. Every second spent re-finding products is wasted. Recently Ordered + one-click reorder = loyalty driver.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Requires order history integration. Consider showing frequency ("You order this every 3 weeks"), quantity suggestions, and easy re-order with quantity adjustment.

features.title: Complementary Products
features.desc: Surface products often bought together based on aggregate purchase patterns. "Often Bought Together" displays.
features.value: Increase basket size by showing what other buyers purchased with this item. Data-driven cross-sell.
features.implementation: Requires transaction history analysis. Can start with curated bundles, improve with behavioral data.

fullContent.whatItSolves: Buyers often forget related items they need for a job. They buy the motor but forget the mounting hardware, capacitor, or VFD. This leads to incomplete orders, return trips, and frustrated customers.
keyValueProps: Show "Often Bought Together" based on real purchase data
Reduce incomplete orders and return trips
Surface accessories, consumables, and related parts automatically
Build bundles based on what actually sells together
useCases: Buyer views a motor → sees mounting hardware, capacitors, and VFDs that others purchased
Electrician adds wire → sees connectors, conduit, and boxes commonly bought together
HVAC tech orders a compressor → sees refrigerant, fittings, and gauges as complements
Plumber views a water heater → sees expansion tanks, connectors, and venting kits
fullContent.b2bContext: Unlike Recommendation Engine (personalized to the user), Complementary Products shows what ALL buyers typically purchase together. It's aggregate intelligence: "85% of buyers who purchased this motor also bought these mounting brackets." This is job-completion data, not personalization.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Requires transaction history to identify co-purchase patterns. Cold start with curated product relationships (merchandiser-defined bundles), then enhance with actual purchase data. Consider confidence thresholds — only show "often bought together" when the pattern is strong.

features.title: Curations
features.desc: Pin, boost, bury, redirect — merchandiser control over search results.
features.value: Promote high-margin items, feature seasonal products, manage campaigns.
features.implementation: Needs training. Can break things if misused. Requires governance.

fullContent.whatItSolves: Business users locked out of search results. Marketing wants to promote a campaign, but has to file an IT ticket and wait.
keyValueProps: Boost or bury products in results
fullContent.b2bContext: Distributors run manufacturer promotions, seasonal campaigns, and clearance sales. Curations let merchandisers control what appears without touching code. But power = responsibility — governance is critical.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Needs training — curations can break relevance if misused. Governance workflow recommended. Start with redirects and pins, expand to boosts carefully.

features.title: Configuration Management
features.desc: Version control for search settings. Track changes, rollback, audit trail.
features.value: Safety net for changes. Know who changed what, when. Easy recovery.
features.implementation: Platform capability. Essential for governance.

fullContent.whatItSolves: The "who changed what?" problem. When search breaks, you need to know what changed and rollback quickly.
keyValueProps: Version control for all search settings
fullContent.b2bContext: Enterprise requirement: know who changed what, when. When search relevance tanks, you need to identify the culprit change and rollback in minutes, not hours.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Platform capability, not a feature to build. Essential foundation for governance. Enables safe experimentation because rollback is easy.

features.title: Query Behaviour Labeller
features.desc: Classify and understand search patterns — navigational, transactional, informational.
features.value: Know how buyers search to inform merchandising and content strategy.
features.implementation: Analytical tool. Informs other features and decisions.

fullContent.whatItSolves: Understanding what buyers actually want when they search. "Milwaukee" — are they looking for the brand page, a product, or information?
fullContent.b2bContext: Helps answer strategic questions: "What % of searches are for exact part numbers vs. product categories?" "What are buyers searching for that we don't carry?" Informs both search tuning and inventory decisions.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Analytical tool that informs other features. Low risk, high insight. Requires behavioral data to accumulate first.

features.title: Search Sandbox
features.desc: Test search changes safely before deploying to production.
features.value: Experiment without risk. Try configurations, preview results.
features.implementation: Essential for safe operations. All three pillars green.

fullContent.whatItSolves: Fear of breaking production. Teams avoid improving search because they can't test safely.
fullContent.b2bContext: All three pillars green — no excuse not to have this. Enables confidence in making changes. Without sandbox, teams either never improve search or break production regularly.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Essential Day 1 infrastructure. Platform capability that enables all other improvement work. Critical for governance and confidence.

features.title: Search Dashboard
features.desc: Real-time performance visibility — top searches, zero results, conversion metrics.
features.value: Know what's working. Identify problems quickly. Data-driven decisions.
features.implementation: Builds over time as data accumulates. Essential for optimization.

fullContent.whatItSolves: Flying blind. Teams don't know what buyers are searching for, what's failing, or how search impacts revenue.
fullContent.b2bContext: You can't improve what you can't measure. Dashboard answers: "What are our top searches?" "What has high search volume but low conversion?" "What are buyers searching for that returns zero results?"
fullContent.implementationNotes: Builds value over time as behavioral data accumulates. Essential for data-driven optimization. Consider alerting for anomalies (zero-result spike, conversion drop).

features.title: AI Enrichment Dashboard
features.desc: AI-powered content generation with human-in-the-loop approval. Generate rich descriptions, attributes, and cross-references at scale.
features.value: Remove the data barrier. AI generates what's missing, your team reviews and approves. Features unlock in weeks, not months.
features.dataRequired: Basic Catalog (titles, SKUs). AI generates the rest.
features.implementation: Confidence-based workflow: high confidence auto-approves, medium requires review, low flagged for manual attention.

fullContent.whatItSolves: The barrier-to-entry problem. Features like Semantic Search need rich descriptions — you have vendor boilerplate. Faceted Search needs structured attributes — you have inconsistent fields with gaps. Cross-Brand Equivalents needs relationship data — you have a 3-year-old spreadsheet. Traditional answer: hire content writers, spend months cleaning up. Most clients stall here. This pipeline removes the barrier.
keyValueProps: AI generates rich, application-focused descriptions from sparse vendor data
Extracts and infers structured attributes from existing text
Suggests cross-brand equivalents based on matching specifications
Confidence scoring: 90%+ auto-approve, 70-90% human review, <70% flagged
Bulk review interfaces with side-by-side comparison (original vs. generated)
Full audit trail tracking AI-generated vs. human-verified content
useCases: Fast-track Semantic Search: 50K SKUs with one-line descriptions → AI generates rich content for top 10K products → team approves over 2 weeks → Semantic Search launches
Attribute gap-fill: Fasteners have detailed specs, safety category has gaps → AI extracts/infers attributes → Faceted Search becomes consistent
Cross-reference bootstrapping: No relationship data → AI suggests equivalents based on specs → product team reviews → Cross-Brand Equivalents launches with curated data
Ongoing enrichment: New products enter weekly → pipeline auto-generates descriptions/attributes → queued for approval → data quality stays consistent
fullContent.b2bContext: Industrial distributors often have 100K+ SKUs with inconsistent data quality. Manual remediation takes months. AI enrichment lets you generate what features need — descriptions, attributes, synonyms, cross-references — and keep humans in control through confidence-based approval workflows.
otherRequirements: Edit-in-place capability to refine AI suggestions
Integration with search index for automatic publishing of approved content
fullContent.implementationNotes: Start with highest-traffic products where data gaps hurt most. Configure confidence thresholds based on category (technical products may need lower auto-approve threshold). Train reviewers on efficient bulk workflows. Track approval rates to tune AI over time.

features.title: Zero Results Recovery
features.desc: Always show something relevant — suggestions, related products, categories.
features.value: Zero results = lost sale. Never dead-end the buyer.
features.implementation: Configure fallback strategies. Test thoroughly.

fullContent.whatItSolves: The worst search outcome: "No results found." Every zero-result page is a potential lost sale and frustrated customer.
keyValueProps: Popular alternatives when exact match fails
fullContent.b2bContext: Zero results in B2B often means the buyer goes to a competitor. Recovery strategies: spelling correction, category suggestions, popular products, "call us" CTA. Something is always better than nothing.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Configure fallback strategies in priority order. Test with actual zero-result queries from logs. Consider capturing zero-result queries for catalog gap analysis.

features.title: Fallback Search
features.desc: Graceful degradation when primary search fails or returns poor results.
features.value: Resilience. If semantic fails, fall back to keyword. Always return results.
features.implementation: Configure fallback chain. Automatic, low governance.

fullContent.whatItSolves: Complex search strategies can fail. What happens when semantic search returns poor results? Fallback provides resilience.
keyValueProps: Automatic fallback when primary search underperforms
fullContent.b2bContext: If semantic search fails to understand a query, fall back to keyword. If keyword fails, fall back to category. The buyer should never experience a broken search.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Configure fallback chain: semantic → keyword → fuzzy → category → popular. Automatic, low governance. Logs fallback events for analysis.

features.title: Analytics
features.desc: Deep-dive search performance metrics, reports, and insights.
features.value: Understand search health. Find opportunities. Prove ROI.
features.implementation: Value increases over time. Essential for optimization.

fullContent.whatItSolves: You can't improve what you can't measure. Without analytics, search optimization is guesswork.
fullContent.b2bContext: Analytics answers strategic questions: "What's the revenue impact of search?" "Which queries have high volume but low conversion?" "What would happen if we improved X?" ROI justification for search investment.
fullContent.implementationNotes: Value increases over time as data accumulates. Start with basic metrics Day 1, add sophisticated analysis as behavioral data grows. Essential for proving ROI.
